awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Science Community of Active Learners to Enhance Achievement and Retention
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University (FAMU) seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines.  The goal of the project is to significantly improve student success rates in the STEM programs in the College of Science and Technology.

The project focuses on the objectives to improve the academic preparedness of freshman STEM students so they are better equipped for the rigor of major courses, graduate school, and the global marketplace; and to increase retention and graduation rates of STEM majors. The following activities and strategies are designed in support of meeting the objectives: improving students' preparedness in mathematics early in the academic career; ensuring that students develop sound foundational knowledge in core disciplines;  helping students develop positive attitudes about their ability to learn; placing students in effective learning environments; providing students with sufficient academic support resources throughout their academic career; and developing and enhancing critical thinking skills. These project strategies are evidence-based, but will be studied for effectiveness in the setting of this university.  The project will be advised and evaluated for effectiveness by internal and external advisory boards and by a team of evaluators. The project at Florida A&M University can serve as a model for the sustainable transformation of the undergraduate STEM curriculum to incorporate evidence-based strategies and practices in STEM education for minority serving institutions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Florida A&M University (FAMU) received an NSF Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) grant entitled “Science Community of Active Learners to Enhance Achievement and Retention (SCALAR).” The project was funded for four years from 2017 through 2021, with a one-year no-cost extension. The overall goal of the project was to significantly improve student success rates in the STEM programs and courses offered by FAMU’s College of Science and Technology (CST). The project sought to 1) improve the academic preparedness of freshman STEM students so they are better equipped for the rigor of upper-division STEM major courses; 2) Increase retention, persistence, and graduation rates of STEM majors; 3) Increase the number of students pursuing STEM degrees; and 4) Provide professional development opportunities for STEM faculty to learn about teaching best practices. 

Through the course of the grant, several curricular and co-curricular activities were implemented that directly impact the culture of student learning at FAMU. Most activities were geared towards freshman STEM students, believing that we can develop the foundational skills to make students better equipped to handle the rigors of STEM programs. In addition, the project had a focus on STEM outreach and faculty development. Some of the highlights and outcomes from these efforts include: 

  • The new course “Scientist Life Skills” (ISC1058) was created and approved by the University in 2018 and was offered for the first time in the Fall of 2018 to all freshman students enrolled in CST. To date, 20 sections of the ISC 1058 class have been offered. A survey administered at the end of each semester revealed that, on average, 60% of the class reported they were “extremely unlikely” or “unlikely” to change their major from STEM. 74% of the class strongly agreed that “I can successfully complete all of my college work if I work hard at it.” 
  • We also offered a Mathematics Boot Camp to incoming CST freshmen, which focused on providing mentorship to increase success and performance in STEM courses, specifically mathematics. The Bootcamp was successful in improving the mathematics performance of the student participants. During the 2020 boot camp, 100% of the program participants who registered for a math course after attending the camp earned passing grades (A, B, or C). 
  • The student seminar series was created to provide students with positive perspectives about STEM study and careers. Fifteen seminars were held from 2017 to 2020. The COVID-19 pandemic interrupted the seminar series in 2020-2021, but we were able to host one in-person seminar in 2022. 
  • The project was responsible for increasing the usage of active learning in the SCALE-UP classrooms on campus. Over the course of the project, 84 class sections were taught in the classrooms. COVID-19 limited usage for the past 2 years.
  • Over the course of the project, more than 3,300 K-12 students have participated in STEM outreach events. The centerpiece outreach activity for the project was the annual STEM Day. Over the five years of the project, STEM Day served more than 1850 students despite being canceled for 2 years (2020 and 2021) due to the pandemic. Other outreach activities conducted include the Summer Academy (210 students served over 3 years), Celebration of Women and Girls in Science (360 students served over 2 years), and STEM Literacy Reading Events (900 students served over 2 years).  
  • From 2017 - 2022, 51 faculty development workshops have covered topics such as active learning, student engagement, classroom management, and throughout the pandemic, teaching using hybrid modalities. Additionally, 23 faculty from the Colleges of Science & Technology and Engineering have participated in summer learning communities related to course redesign, improving student grit, growth mindset, critical thinking, and best practices for remote teaching during the pandemic. Five (5) faculty members and one (1) postdoc have been supported for conference travel to present work on improving teaching and learning in STEM areas.
  • From 2017 (1006) to 2019 (1078), enrollment in the CST STEM programs increased by 7%. Enrollment decreased in 2020 (1069) and 2021(1034) due to the pandemic.
  • Since 2017, the CST first-year retention (77.6%) rate has increased by 7.3% to 83.3% in 2020. 3rd-year retention (64%) also increased 18% to 76.2% during the same period.
  • The 6-year graduation rate for CST graduates increased to 59% in 2021 from 47.5% in 2017. 
  • Course success rates have increased in several gateway courses over the span of the grant. 
    • CHM 1025 (Fundamentals of Chemistry) – 60.84% (2017) to 65.66% (2021)
    • BSC 1010 (General Biology 1) – 64.08% (2017) to 76.59% (2021)
    • MAC 1105 (College Algebra) – 70.48% (2017) to 84.02% (2021)

Overall, the project demonstrated that implementing interrelated academic support, curricular, and co-curricular initiatives using a comprehensive framework can significantly impact and increase STEM student success outcomes. 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2022
Modified by: Maurice Edington
por.por_txt_cntn:
Florida A&M University (FAMU) received an NSF Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) grant entitled "Science Community of Active Learners to Enhance Achievement and Retention (SCALAR)." The project was funded for four years from 2017 through 2021, with a one-year no-cost extension. The overall goal of the project was to significantly improve student success rates in the STEM programs and courses offered by FAMU’s College of Science and Technology (CST). The project sought to 1) improve the academic preparedness of freshman STEM students so they are better equipped for the rigor of upper-division STEM major courses; 2) Increase retention, persistence, and graduation rates of STEM majors; 3) Increase the number of students pursuing STEM degrees; and 4) Provide professional development opportunities for STEM faculty to learn about teaching best practices. 

Through the course of the grant, several curricular and co-curricular activities were implemented that directly impact the culture of student learning at FAMU. Most activities were geared towards freshman STEM students, believing that we can develop the foundational skills to make students better equipped to handle the rigors of STEM programs. In addition, the project had a focus on STEM outreach and faculty development. Some of the highlights and outcomes from these efforts include: 

The new course "Scientist Life Skills" (ISC1058) was created and approved by the University in 2018 and was offered for the first time in the Fall of 2018 to all freshman students enrolled in CST. To date, 20 sections of the ISC 1058 class have been offered. A survey administered at the end of each semester revealed that, on average, 60% of the class reported they were "extremely unlikely" or "unlikely" to change their major from STEM. 74% of the class strongly agreed that "I can successfully complete all of my college work if I work hard at it." 
We also offered a Mathematics Boot Camp to incoming CST freshmen, which focused on providing mentorship to increase success and performance in STEM courses, specifically mathematics. The Bootcamp was successful in improving the mathematics performance of the student participants. During the 2020 boot camp, 100% of the program participants who registered for a math course after attending the camp earned passing grades (A, B, or C). 
The student seminar series was created to provide students with positive perspectives about STEM study and careers. Fifteen seminars were held from 2017 to 2020. The COVID-19 pandemic interrupted the seminar series in 2020-2021, but we were able to host one in-person seminar in 2022. 
The project was responsible for increasing the usage of active learning in the SCALE-UP classrooms on campus. Over the course of the project, 84 class sections were taught in the classrooms. COVID-19 limited usage for the past 2 years.
Over the course of the project, more than 3,300 K-12 students have participated in STEM outreach events. The centerpiece outreach activity for the project was the annual STEM Day. Over the five years of the project, STEM Day served more than 1850 students despite being canceled for 2 years (2020 and 2021) due to the pandemic. Other outreach activities conducted include the Summer Academy (210 students served over 3 years), Celebration of Women and Girls in Science (360 students served over 2 years), and STEM Literacy Reading Events (900 students served over 2 years).  
From 2017 - 2022, 51 faculty development workshops have covered topics such as active learning, student engagement, classroom management, and throughout the pandemic, teaching using hybrid modalities. Additionally, 23 faculty from the Colleges of Science & Technology and Engineering have participated in summer learning communities related to course redesign, improving student grit, growth mindset, critical thinking, and best practices for remote teaching during the pandemic. Five (5) faculty members and one (1) postdoc have been supported for conference travel to present work on improving teaching and learning in STEM areas.
From 2017 (1006) to 2019 (1078), enrollment in the CST STEM programs increased by 7%. Enrollment decreased in 2020 (1069) and 2021(1034) due to the pandemic.
Since 2017, the CST first-year retention (77.6%) rate has increased by 7.3% to 83.3% in 2020. 3rd-year retention (64%) also increased 18% to 76.2% during the same period.
The 6-year graduation rate for CST graduates increased to 59% in 2021 from 47.5% in 2017. 
Course success rates have increased in several gateway courses over the span of the grant.   

CHM 1025 (Fundamentals of Chemistry) – 60.84% (2017) to 65.66% (2021)
BSC 1010 (General Biology 1) – 64.08% (2017) to 76.59% (2021)
MAC 1105 (College Algebra) – 70.48% (2017) to 84.02% (2021)




Overall, the project demonstrated that implementing interrelated academic support, curricular, and co-curricular initiatives using a comprehensive framework can significantly impact and increase STEM student success outcomes.
